stem: A 41-year-old client with Graves' disease is brought to the ED after undergoing an emergency appendectomy. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The client is experiencing a post-operative hypermetabolic crisis following an emergency appendectomy. The client has a history of Graves' disease and poor compliance with methimazole. The client is extremely agitated, diaphoretic, and tremulous. Vital signs are unstable.

Background: The client has a known history of Graves' disease, complicated by poor medication adherence. The appendectomy was performed at 02:00 today. The client's thyroid condition was not optimized pre-operatively.

Assessment: At 08:00, the client's vital signs are: BP 168/110 mmHg, HR 162 bpm (A-fib), RR 34 breaths/min, T 105.2°F (40.7°C), SpO2 91% on room air. The client is confused and disoriented.

Recommendation: Initiate immediate interventions to address suspected thyroid storm, including cooling measures, beta-blockers, and continuous monitoring. Consult endocrinology STAT.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
• Methimazole 20mg PO daily (non-compliant)
  • Morphine 4mg IV PRN pain (x1 dose post-op)
  • Ondansetron 4mg IV PRN nausea (x1 dose post-op)

actionOptions.text: Apply cooling blankets and ice packs to the groin and axilla
Apply warm blankets to treat shivering

parameterOptions.text: Cardiac rhythm (Atrial Fibrillation vs Sinus Tachycardia)
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is a classic Thyroid Storm (c1) often triggered by a stressful event like surgery in a client with poorly controlled hyperthyroidism. Symptoms include extreme fever (105.2°F/40.7°C), severe tachycardia (162 bpm) with atrial fibrillation, and delirium. The priority is to rapidly reduce the temperature (a1) using cooling blankets and ice packs, and to control the heart rate and sympathetic surge with beta-blockers like propranolol (a2). Continuous monitoring of core temperature (p1) and cardiac rhythm (p2) is critical to detect complications such as heart failure or cardiac arrest. The undetectable TSH and elevated T3/T4 confirm thyrotoxicosis.
clinicalPearls: In thyroid storm, avoid aspirin for fever management as it can worsen the condition by displacing thyroid hormone from binding proteins. Acetaminophen is the preferred antipyretic.
Thyroid storm carries a high mortality risk due to the potential for heart failure resulting from the increased metabolic demands.

Propranolol is beneficial in thyroid storm not only for its beta-blocking effects but also because it inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3, further reducing thyroid hormone activity.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting Dantrolene (a3) due to the high temperature, mistaking the condition for Malignant Hyperthermia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Dantrolene is the treatment for Malignant Hyperthermia, which is typically triggered by anesthesia or succinylcholine. If the client has a history of Graves' disease or hyperthyroidism, consider Thyroid Storm as the more likely diagnosis.

mnemonic.title: STORM Cues
mnemonic.expansion: S-Surgery/Stress trigger. T-Tachycardia. O-Overheating (Fever). R-Restlessness/Agitation. M-Metabolic Crisis.
